title: Quiz 8: Clinical Scenarios
topicName: HIV, AIDS and STIs Comprehensive Teaching Manual
description: Apply your knowledge to clinical scenarios involving HIV/STI diagnosis, treatment, and counseling.

questions.question: Scenario: A 28-year-old male presents with a painful genital ulcer and swollen inguinal lymph nodes. Which condition is most likely?

richContent.content: Patient History: Sexually active, inconsistent condom use. Ulcer is soft with undefined edges.

questions.explanation: Painful, soft ulcers suggest Chancroid. Syphilis ulcers are typically painless.

questions.question: Scenario: A pregnant woman tests HIV positive. Which interventions are indicated for eMTCT? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Provide ARV prophylaxis to the infant

questions.explanation: Immediate ART for mother, prophylaxis for infant, and safe delivery are key. Breastfeeding is recommended WITH ARV cover.
questions.hint: Breastfeeding is generally safe if on meds.

questions.question: A healthcare worker suffers a needle-stick injury while drawing blood from an HIV-positive patient. What specific intervention must be started within 72 hours?
questions.explanation: PEP is the standard of care for occupational exposure.
questions.hint: Acronym for the preventative treatment after exposure.

questions.question: Match the clinical finding to the likely WHO Stage:
A patient on ART complains of vivid dreams and dizziness. This is likely a side effect of ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: CNS side effects are hallmark of Efavirenz.

questions.question: A client tests reactive on the first rapid test but non-reactive on the second. What is the immediate next step?
questions.explanation: Inconclusive results require a tie-breaker test (ELISA).

questions.question: A male patient presenting with urethral discharge should be treated for both Gonorrhea and Chlamydia.
questions.explanation: Syndromic management dictates treating for the most common causes, which are Gonorrhea and Chlamydia.

questions.question: Order the steps in managing a patient with Cryptococcal Meningitis:
questions.explanation: Treat CM first, wait 4-6 weeks, then start ART to avoid IRIS.
questions.hint: Treat the infection before boosting the immune system.
